concept.title: Cluster setup considerations
concept.shortdesc: Proper configuration of I/O subsystems is critical for the optimal performance and operation and performance of Couchbase Server.

conbody.p: These are the most common best practices recommended for storage configuration:

dlentry.dt: Use RAID 1+0 (or RAID 1) if replication factor is 1
dlentry.dd: If replication factor is 2 or higher, the system administrator can rely on database-level replication for data durability.

MDS functionality allows separation of Index and Query services from the traditional Couchbase Server data/view services. With MDS and if it fits your use case needs, you can have different disk storage configurations for cluster nodes running the Data service and different ones running the Index service. For example, nodes running the Index service could have SSD backed storage for better performance. Please refer to .
For Windows OS, use 64k allocation sizes on NTFS file systems.
For best performance, isolate the data and indexes (note that these are different from the Index service) at the physical disk level.

Combining different workloads (workloads with very different I/O and latency characteristics) can have a negative effect on the overall performance. In case of combined workloads, it might be appropriate to have objects in different buckets and the files for each bucket on different mount points/paths.
